questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health examination. She feels well and asks for advice about smoking cessation. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years. She wants to quit smoking but she is not yet ready to set a specific date. She has tried to quit several times in the past without success. During the previous attempts, she had anxiety and gained weight. She has also tried nicotine lozenges but stopped taking them because of severe headaches. She has bulimia nervosa. She does not drink throughout the week but consumes 8–10 alcoholic beverages on weekends. She takes no medications. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to behavioral interventions, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management regarding smoking cessation at this visit?

choices.text: No further management at this visit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Some individuals are able to quit smoking without medical intervention. Nevertheless, all patients who wish to quit smoking should be offered medical management. As this patient has tried to quit multiple times, additional management will likely benefit her current attempt at smoking cessation.

B) CORRECT:

Varenicline is a first-line treatment for smoking cessation as it reduces craving and withdrawal symptoms. In patients who are unable to set a quit date, medication preloading with varenicline (i.e., pharmacotherapy while the patient is still smoking) reduces smoking in the weeks leading up to the quit date and increases the likelihood of sustained abstinence rates in the future. In addition to being a safe drug for smoking cessation, varenicline is slightly more effective than bupropion, an alternative management option. A combination of pharmacological and behavioral intervention leads to better results for patients who wish to quit smoking.

C) INCORRECT:

Buspirone is a therapy for patients with generalized anxiety disorder and is not a part of smoking cessation management.

D) INCORRECT:

Naltrexone is a long-acting opioid antagonist that is used to promote alcohol cessation in patients with alcohol use disorder and to manage withdrawal symptoms after acute opioid detoxification. Although it is being evaluated for its efficacy in smoking cessation, it is currently not recommended as a first-line smoking cessation aid.

E) INCORRECT:

Bupropion is a first-line agent for smoking cessation. However, it is contraindicated in patients who have predisposing conditions that increase the risk of seizures (e.g., seizure disorders, anorexia or bulimia nervosa, alcohol withdrawal, abrupt discontinuation of benzodiazepines) because it reduces the seizure threshold.

F) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). SSRIs are first-line drugs for the treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD), generalized anxiety disorder, OCD, and bulimia nervosa. They are not an effective therapy for smoking cessation.
questions.hint: Conditions that increase the risk of seizures (including eating disorders and binge drinking) are a contraindication to certain medications.

In addition to nicotine patches, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

E-cigarettes can suppress withdrawal symptoms because they contain nicotine. However, e-cigarettes are not a recommended form of NRT as their long-term effects have not been studied.

B) INCORRECT:

Although hypnotherapy is sometimes used as an adjunctive therapy for patients who wish to stop smoking, there is insufficient evidence to support its use.

C) CORRECT:

Combined nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) involves the use of a long-acting nicotine receptor agonist (e.g., patch) along with a short-acting nicotine receptor agonist (e.g., lozenge). This combination treats both withdrawal symptoms and acute cravings and is therefore more effective for smoking cessation than using only one form of NRT. Patients using NRT should be followed up closely to assess for efficacy and side effects. First-line pharmacological treatment alternatives to combined NRT include varenicline and bupropion, which also reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms.

Additionally, behavioral interventions (e.g., counseling) should always be offered as part of first-line therapy to help individuals modify their smoking habits.

D) INCORRECT:

Although monotherapy with nicotine patches reduces nicotine withdrawal symptoms, it does not relieve acute cravings. Adding another treatment increases the likelihood of treatment success.

E) INCORRECT:

Although acupuncture is included in some smoking cessation programs, there is insufficient evidence to support its use.
questions.hint: Nicotine patch monotherapy reduces withdrawal symptoms but does not alleviate acute cravings in individuals trying to quit smoking.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, comes to the physician 3 days after a home pregnancy test was positive. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child 4 years ago were uncomplicated. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the last 10 years but refrained from smoking during her first pregnancy. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.1 g/dL and a serum β-hCG of 2,000 mIU/ml. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a gestational sac consistent with a 5-week pregnancy. When asked about her willingness to quit smoking, the patient replies that she is worried that she won't be able to quit because the frequency of her smoking has increased since the birth of her first child. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intervention to support smoking cessation in this patient?

choices.text: Use of a transdermal nicotine patch

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) with transdermal nicotine patches is a first-line treatment for smoking cessation in nonpregnant patients. Because its effects on the fetus are not entirely known, NRT is not a first-line treatment during pregnancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Bupropion is a first-line treatment for smoking cessation in nonpregnant patients. Because its effects on the fetus are not entirely known, bupropion is not a first-line treatment for pregnant patients.

C) CORRECT:

Behavioral counseling is the first-line intervention for smoking cessation in pregnant individuals and includes frequent (e.g., weekly) office visits and/or telephone counseling for behavioral therapy, motivational interviewing, and the provision of self-help materials. Although pharmacotherapy (e.g., nicotine replacement therapy, varenicline, bupropion) is often used in combination with behavioral interventions in nonpregnant individuals, the safety and efficacy of these medications have not been established in pregnant individuals. Therefore, pharmacotherapy is used on an individual basis in pregnant patients who do not respond to behavioral interventions, when the clinician determines that its benefits outweigh its risks (e.g., in heavy tobacco use).

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) with nicotine gum is a first-line treatment for smoking cessation in nonpregnant individuals. Because its effects on the fetus are not entirely known, NRT is not a first-line treatment during pregnancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Varenicline is a first-line treatment for smoking cessation in nonpregnant patients. Because its effects on the fetus are not entirely known, varenicline is not a first-line treatment during pregnancy.
questions.hint: Treatment recommendations for smoking cessation may differ between pregnant and nonpregnant patients.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman reports that she smokes one pack of cigarettes daily but is ready to quit and would like assistance. She previously had short-term success with varenicline but stopped the medication because of disturbing dreams and insomnia. Attempts to quit cold turkey have been unsuccessful.
Her medical history includes two idiopathic convulsive seizures that occurred about 5 years ago; she took an anticonvulsant drug for 2 years and has had no recurrence of seizures since stopping it. She is not currently taking any medications.
She has a blood pressure of 116/76 mm Hg, a heart rate of 70 beats per minute, and a BMI of 26. She has poor dentition with some gingival inflammation but no other oral mucosal abnormalities. Her physical examination is otherwise unremarkable.
In addition to behavior-modification counseling, which one of the following pharmacologic therapies is most appropriate to aid this patient in smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In clinical trials, combinations of a long-acting form of NRT (such as the patch) with a short-acting form (such as the lozenge or gum) tended to yield higher success rates than a single form of NRT.

B) INCORRECT:

Gum may not be as well tolerated as lozenges in patients with poor dentition, dentures, or temporomandibular joint disease; hence the lozenge would be a better choice for this patient with poor dentition.

C) CORRECT:

The choice of pharmacologic agent for smoking cessation depends on patient preference, previous history with smoking cessation therapies, and comorbidities that might preclude certain drug therapies.

Dual (oral and patch) nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), varenicline, and bupropion are considered first-line pharmacologic treatments for smoking cessation. Varenicline is not appropriate for this patient because of her previous adverse experience with it (disturbing dreams and insomnia are known side effects). Bupropion can lower seizure threshold and is contraindicated in patients with seizures; thus, it should be avoided in this patient with relatively recent seizures.

NRT products available in the United States include the nicotine patch, lozenge, gum, nasal spray, and inhaler. In clinical trials, combinations of a long-acting form of NRT (such as the patch) with a short-acting form (such as the lozenge or gum) tended to yield higher success rates than a single form of NRT. Gum may not be as well tolerated as lozenges in patients with poor dentition, dentures, or temporomandibular joint disease; hence the lozenge would be a better choice for this patient with poor dentition.

Clinicians play a key role in assessing patients' readiness to quit smoking and providing resources that maximize success in quitting. In a study published in 2013, patients who agreed to be connected to phone-based tobacco “quit lines” (staffed by smoking-cessation counselors) were more likely to enroll in treatment when they were called proactively by the quit line than when they were expected to call the quit line themselves.

Key learning point: The most appropriate pharmacologic intervention for smoking cessation in a woman with a history of seizures who cannot tolerate varenicline is dual nicotine replacement therapy (patch and oral).

D) INCORRECT:

Selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors, such as sertraline, have not convincingly been shown to be effective in smoking cessation.

E) INCORRECT:

Bupropion can lower seizure threshold and is contraindicated in patients with seizures; thus, it should be avoided in this patient with relatively recent seizures.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man requests help with smoking cessation. He has been smoking a few cigarettes a day since he was a teenager, but the frequency increased markedly during the past year. On examination, he smells like smoke, appears disheveled, and seems to be sadder than during previous visits. On further questioning, he reports that he has difficulty sleeping, trouble concentrating, and very little energy; he feels sluggish and is struggling at work. He reports no current suicidal ideation.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

First-line treatments for smoking cessation include bupropion, varenicline, and nicotine replacement (in a variety of forms — gum, inhaler, lozenge, nasal spray, and patch). Although some data suggest that varenicline is superior to bupropion and nicotine, patient preferences and the presence of comorbidities may guide the choice of therapy. In this case, the patient is requesting help with his tobacco use, but he also has features of depression. In this scenario, bupropion may be preferable because it is effective for the management of both diagnoses.

Nicotine replacement will not directly treat symptoms of depression. It also does not promote cessation as well as bupropion in the setting of depression. In a large randomized trial of smokers, bupropion and nicotine replacement were associated with similar rates of tobacco abstinence overall. However, in those with a history of depression, bupropion led to significantly higher rates of abstinence than nicotine replacement.

Key learning point: Bupropion should be strongly considered in patients who request help with tobacco use and have comorbid depression.

B) INCORRECT:

Varenicline helps with smoking cessation and has been shown to be safe and effective, including in patients with known psychiatric disease. However, it does not treat depression and is therefore not the best option in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine is a suitable and effective medication to treat depression, but it does not treat tobacco use.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotine replacement will not directly treat symptoms of depression. It also does not promote cessation as well as bupropion in the setting of depression. In a large randomized trial of smokers, bupropion and nicotine replacement were associated with similar rates of tobacco abstinence overall. However, in those with a history of depression, bupropion led to significantly higher rates of abstinence than nicotine replacement.

E) INCORRECT:

Nicotine replacement will not directly treat symptoms of depression. It also does not promote cessation as well as bupropion in the setting of depression. In a large randomized trial of smokers, bupropion and nicotine replacement were associated with similar rates of tobacco abstinence overall. However, in those with a history of depression, bupropion led to significantly higher rates of abstinence than nicotine replacement.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with a 25-year smoking history struggles to quit despite cough and exertional dyspnea. On exam, mild wheezing is noted. What mechanism best explains his persistent tobacco use?

choices.text: Reduced mucociliary clearance perpetuating chronic cough
Increased alveolar oxygenation providing symptomatic relief
Enhanced dopaminergic signaling via nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the reward pathway
Heightened endorphin release from peripheral opioid receptors

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic smoking impairs mucociliary clearance, contributing to chronic cough and infection risk. However, nicotine addiction is driven by its effects on central reward pathways, not by impaired airway clearance.

B) INCORRECT:

Cigarette smoke impairs oxygen transfer by introducing carbon monoxide and other toxins, reducing hemoglobin's oxygen-carrying capacity and damaging alveoli. The symptomatic relief smokers report is due to nicotine's central nervous system effects, not improved oxygenation.

C) CORRECT:

Nicotine binds to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the ventral tegmental area, increasing dopamine release in the nucleus accumbens. This enhanced dopaminergic signaling in the mesolimbic reward pathway reinforces nicotine use by creating pleasurable sensations and strong conditioning effects. Neuroadaptations maintain dependence, making cessation challenging, despite adverse respiratory symptoms.

Key learning point: Nicotine is the primary addictive component of tobacco products, leading to continued use and exposure to harmful chemicals that cause diseases like COPD, lung cancer, and heart diseases.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotine's reinforcing effects are mediated by central nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the mesolimbic dopamine system, not peripheral opioid receptors. Peripheral opioid receptors regulate pain and gastrointestinal functions, not substance dependence.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man, who smoked for 15 years, reports strong cravings and irritability on day three of quitting. Which statement correctly describes nicotine withdrawal?

choices.text: Symptoms begin after 7 days and intensify over 3 weeks
Symptoms peak at 2–4 days and gradually subside
Symptoms fully resolve by 24 hours with minimal relapse risk
Symptoms peak after 3 weeks and persist for several months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nicotine withdrawal symptoms usually begin within hours to a day after cessation, peaking around days 2 to 3. They typically subside over 2 to 4 weeks, not intensifying over 3 weeks. The patient's symptoms on day three align with the expected early onset and peak of withdrawal.

B) CORRECT:

Nicotine withdrawal is characterized by neuroadaptive changes due to chronic nicotine use, affecting nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Upon cessation, the rapid decline in plasma nicotine levels triggers withdrawal symptoms such as cravings, irritability, anxiety, and difficulty concentrating. These symptoms typically peak within 2 to 4 days as the body adjusts its neurochemical balance. Understanding this timeline helps clinicians anticipate symptom severity and plan supportive interventions during early smoking cessation.

Key learning point: Nicotine withdrawal symptoms peak 2 to 4 days after smoking cessation, with symptoms gradually decreasing thereafter.

C) INCORRECT:

Nicotine withdrawal symptoms do not resolve within 24 hours. They peak around 24 to 72 hours and can persist for weeks. The patient's cravings and irritability on day three reflect the peak withdrawal period, which is associated with a high relapse risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotine withdrawal symptoms peak within 2 to 3 days, not after 3 weeks. While some cravings may linger, the most severe symptoms typically subside within a couple of weeks. The patient's symptoms on day three indicate the early peak of withdrawal.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a 20-year smoking history has repeatedly relapsed. Which factor most strongly predicts successful cessation?

choices.text: Frequent follow-up visits with a clinician
Participation in a group counseling program

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Frequent follow-up visits support smoking cessation by reinforcing strategies and managing challenges. However, they serve as an adjunct rather than the primary driver of success. Intrinsic motivation and personal commitment have a more substantial impact on long-term abstinence than the frequency of clinician contact.

B) INCORRECT:

Group counseling provides social support and behavioral strategies, modestly improving quit rates. However, its impact is less robust than intrinsic factors like personal commitment and readiness to change. The effectiveness of group counseling varies based on program structure and individual engagement.

C) INCORRECT:

Nicotine replacement therapy, such as a 12-week patch regimen, helps reduce withdrawal symptoms by providing steady nicotine levels. However, while it addresses physiological dependence, it does not address the behavioral and psychological components of smoking addiction. Intrinsic motivation and readiness to change are more critical for long-term cessation success.

D) CORRECT:

Intrinsic motivation is a crucial determinant of smoking cessation success. It reflects an individual's internal drive and readiness to change, which are essential for adopting long-term lifestyle modifications. This motivation empowers individuals to engage with cessation strategies, manage withdrawal symptoms, and cope with triggers. High intrinsic motivation aligns with behavioral change models, emphasizing personal readiness in transitioning through stages of change. It facilitates the integration of behavioral and pharmacologic interventions, supporting sustained smoking abstinence.

Key learning point: The patient's intrinsic motivation and desire to quit smoking is the most important factor in determining the success of a smoking cessation program.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents requesting guidance to quit smoking. He has a 30-year history of smoking 1.5 packs per day and reports multiple failed attempts to quit. He experiences irritability, difficulty concentrating, and strong nicotine cravings whenever he stops tobacco use. He has tried reducing the number of cigarettes and switching to lighter brands but continues to experience withdrawal symptoms. He has no known psychiatric or medical comorbidities. Physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abrupt cessation, or quitting 'cold turkey,' is less suitable for this patient due to his high nicotine dependence and significant withdrawal symptoms. Without support, withdrawal becomes more intense and less tolerable, making pharmacologic and behavioral support more appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is the primary intervention for this patient due to his long history of heavy smoking and withdrawal symptoms. NRT provides controlled nicotine delivery through patches, gums, or lozenges, reducing withdrawal symptoms like irritability and cravings. This allows the patient to focus on behavioral changes without the discomfort of nicotine absence. Gradual tapering of nicotine supports neuroadaptation and reduces tobacco reliance. NRT's efficacy is well-documented and endorsed by clinical guidelines for smoking cessation, especially in individuals with a history of heavy use.

Key learning point: Nicotine replacement therapy is the most appropriate initial therapy for heavy smokers seeking to quit, as it helps alleviate withdrawal symptoms and reduce the urge to smoke.

C) INCORRECT:

Clonidine, an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, may alleviate withdrawal symptoms but is limited by side effects like hypotension and sedation. Its efficacy in smoking cessation is less robust compared to first-line therapies like nicotine replacement, bupropion, or varenicline.

D) INCORRECT:

Nortriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant, is considered after failure of standard therapies or in those with mood disorders. This patient lacks psychiatric comorbidities, making first-line therapies like nicotine replacement, bupropion, or varenicline more appropriate due to their favorable safety profile.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with a 40-year smoking history presents for a routine follow-up. He has hypertension, managed on medication, but continues to smoke a pack daily. Previous advice to quit has been met with resistance, and he becomes visibly irritated whenever asked about cessation, citing stress relief as his main reason for continuing. He denies any interest in nicotine replacement options. Physical exam is unremarkable except for mild nicotine staining on his fingers. Which strategy is most likely to influence him toward considering smoking cessation?

choices.text: Warn him that refusing to quit makes him ineligible for further medical follow-up
Threaten him with negative outcomes by showing graphic, fear-inducing images
Acknowledge his hesitation, express empathy, and offer cessation support whenever he feels ready
Demand setting a firm quit date during this visit to avoid future complications

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This coercive strategy undermines the therapeutic alliance and may exacerbate resistance. It relies on threats rather than fostering empathetic dialogue. Evidence-based smoking cessation approaches advocate for motivational interviewing and patient-centered counseling, which respect autonomy and address ambivalence with empathy. Punitive tactics can damage trust and reduce future intervention opportunities.

B) INCORRECT:

Fear-based interventions may provoke emotional reactions but are ineffective for patients resistant to cessation discussions. This patient uses smoking as a stress coping mechanism, and confrontational tactics may elicit defensiveness. Fear appeals are less effective for individuals in the precontemplative stage of change, where empathetic, patient-centered counseling is more appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

This approach aligns with motivational interviewing principles, emphasizing empathy and patient-centered care. Acknowledging the patient's hesitation and expressing empathy validates his feelings, reducing defensiveness. By offering support when he is ready, this strategy respects his autonomy and builds rapport, facilitating a collaborative therapeutic relationship. This approach allows healthcare providers to introduce evidence-based cessation options at a pace aligned with the patient's readiness, addressing nicotine's role in stress regulation.

Key learning point: In communication with patients who refuse to stop smoking, a supportive and non-judgmental approach that offers assistance is more effective than confrontational or coercive statements.

D) INCORRECT:

This directive approach assumes readiness to quit, which is not evident in this patient. He shows ambivalence and uses smoking for stress relief. Imposing a quit date can be perceived as coercive, exacerbating resistance and undermining the therapeutic relationship. Strategies exploring ambivalence and motivating gradual change are more effective for patients in the precontemplative or early contemplative phases.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, 12 weeks pregnant, smokes 10 cigarettes per day and wants to quit. What is the most appropriate initial management step?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Behavioral therapy is the preferred initial management for smoking cessation during pregnancy, as it avoids fetal exposure to medications. Techniques such as motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy help patients modify behavior and quit smoking. This approach addresses the specific challenges faced by pregnant women, offering personalized support and strategies to overcome nicotine dependence while emphasizing the benefits of cessation for maternal and fetal health.

Key learning point: Behavioral therapy is the safest and most recommended first-line intervention for smoking cessation in pregnant women, as it avoids the potential risks associated with pharmacological treatments.

B) INCORRECT:

Varenicline, a partial agonist at nicotinic receptors, reduces nicotine cravings but lacks sufficient safety data for use during pregnancy, especially in the first and early second trimesters. Concerns about potential teratogenic effects and adverse fetal outcomes make it less suitable compared to strategies with more established safety profiles, such as behavioral interventions.

C) INCORRECT:

Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant used for smoking cessation, but its use during pregnancy is approached with caution due to limited safety data. This patient is 12 weeks pregnant and has no depressive symptoms. Nonpharmacologic measures are prioritized for smoking cessation during pregnancy to minimize fetal exposure to medications.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is considered for pregnant women who are heavy smokers or have failed nonpharmacologic interventions. However, this patient smokes a relatively low number of cigarettes and is early in her pregnancy, favoring behavioral counseling. NRT avoids harmful substances in tobacco smoke, but the safety of nicotine in pregnancy is not fully established.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea for 2 years and frequent morning sputum production to the clinic. He has a 35-year pack history of smoking and continues to smoke one pack per day. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds and a prolonged expiratory phase. Pulmonary spirometry is consistent with moderate COPD. He has not started any medications but is concerned about worsening breathing.

Oxygen saturation
94% on room air

Which intervention is most likely to slow further deterioration of this patient’s lung function?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Smoking cessation is the most effective intervention for slowing the progression of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Cigarette smoke exposure leads to airway inflammation, oxidative stress, and protease-antiprotease imbalance, accelerating lung function decline. A structured program, including behavioral counseling and pharmacologic therapies like nicotine replacement, bupropion, or varenicline, significantly slows the decline in forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1). Landmark studies show improved lung function and reduced exacerbation risks with early smoking cessation, enhancing prognosis and quality of life in COPD patients.

Key learning point: Smoking cessation is the most critical initial step in managing COPD as it slows disease progression and improves survival.

B) INCORRECT:

Long-term supplemental oxygen therapy benefits COPD patients with severe resting hypoxemia, typically with oxygen saturations below 88% or PaO2 below 55 mmHg. This patient has an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air, indicating he does not meet criteria for oxygen therapy. Oxygen therapy primarily improves survival in advanced COPD with significant hypoxemia, not in moderate COPD with preserved oxygenation.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) reduce inflammation and are used in COPD with frequent exacerbations or an asthmatic phenotype. However, in moderate COPD, high-dose ICS do not significantly alter disease progression. The patient's smoking history and chronic bronchitis features suggest airway remodeling and parenchymal destruction, which ICS do not address. High-dose ICS can also increase the risk of side effects like oral candidiasis and pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Long-acting beta-2 agonists (LABAs) provide bronchodilation, improving airflow and symptoms in COPD. They relax airway smooth muscles, enhancing exercise tolerance and quality of life. However, LABAs do not affect the inflammatory processes or structural lung changes driving disease progression. They alleviate symptoms but do not slow the decline in lung function.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents to the ED with chest pain. His workup shows a musculoskeletal etiology. During the encounter, he mentions smoking 1.5 packs of cigarettes daily for 25 years and expresses readiness to quit after two previous unsuccessful attempts. He reports strong morning cravings and typically smokes his first cigarette within 15 minutes of waking. Based on his high nicotine dependence and motivation to quit, what is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Provide educational materials about smoking risks and recommend immediate cessation
Prescribe varenicline with instructions to start immediately
Provide tobacco cessation resources and arrange primary care follow-up
Refer to pulmonology for a specialized tobacco cessation program
Recommend nicotine replacement therapy and discharge home

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Educational materials with immediate cessation advice are insufficient for a motivated individual with high nicotine dependence. This approach does not provide comprehensive cessation support or address the need for pharmacological and/or behavioral interventions.

B) INCORRECT:

While varenicline may be appropriate for this individual, proper treatment planning, withdrawal education, and scheduled follow-up are also required. Emergency physicians should coordinate with primary care for comprehensive cessation support rather than initiate pharmacological treatment in isolation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has high nicotine dependence (smoking within 30 minutes of waking) and expresses readiness to quit. Follow-up with the patient's primary care physician allows for proper treatment planning, including scheduling future visits to monitor attempts to quit and to assess barriers during the critical relapse period. A combination of behavioral and pharmacological therapies increases treatment success.

D) INCORRECT:

Specialty referral is not the immediate next step for routine tobacco cessation. Primary care coordination is more appropriate for initial cessation management, with specialty referral reserved for complex cases or if treatment is unsuccessful.

E) INCORRECT:

Recommending nicotine replacement therapy without specific follow-up does not provide the necessary comprehensive support. Individuals require close monitoring in the first weeks after an attempt to quit because relapse risk is highest during this period.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He asks for advice about smoking cessation, as his past attempts were unsuccessful due to intense cravings. The provider prescribes a drug that acts as a partial agonist at the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naltrexone is a long-acting opioid receptor antagonist that is used to manage withdrawal symptoms of acute opioid detoxification and to curb the amount and frequency of drinking in alcohol dependence. Naltrexone is not an effective therapy for smoking cessation.

B) CORRECT:

Varenicline is a nicotinic acetylcholine receptor partial agonist that is used to treat nicotine dependence. The drug's partial agonism of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor produces a modified dopaminergic response, in contrast to the full dopaminergic outflow to the nucleus accumbens that nicotine binding produces. Varenicline thus reduces the rewarding effects of nicotine and minimizes cravings associated with withdrawal.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is used for the treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD), generalized anxiety disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and bulimia. Fluoxetine is not an effective therapy for smoking cessation.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotine gum is a form of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), which is the first-line treatment for nicotine dependence to reduce smoking. For patients who want to stop smoking, NRT provides nicotine, thereby reducing withdrawal symptoms. The active substance in nicotine gum, however, is a full nicotinic acetylcholine receptor agonist, unlike the drug prescribed to this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Bupropion is a norepinephrine and dopamine uptake inhibitor that can be used for smoking cessation. Although it reduces the withdrawal and craving effects of smoking cessation, bupropion does not act on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, unlike the drug prescribed to this patient.
questions.hint: The adverse effects of this drug, which is used exclusively as a smoking cessation aid, include nausea, headache, and sleep disturbances.
